column1: Capacity Block - Multiple Risks
column35:
*RISK*:  potential year end disconnect between cash and expense would be considered unallowable (if RTX pays for more hours than it receives) or if there’s another approach that’s viable to solve the variance (rate correction, pro-rated allocation based on usage, etc)

*Mitigation:*  Jed, Shelly, Carlos to get with Bob Bracken and Matt Muzerall to ensure we do not have Gov't accounting conflicts.

*Update* 10/20:  If it’s a credit (RTX pays less than hours received) then there should not be an issue from a government accounting standpoint to distribute this credit via rate reduction or proration on usage) 

Tied to story - NOPT-5874

 

*Risk*:  We need to capture labor hours for expense recognition and not only payment.

*Mitigation*:  Jaime/Dave Tracy to discuss technical feasibility.

*Update 10/20:*  

Tied to story - NOPT-7634

 

*Risk*:  Capacity Block price needs to be lower than proposed to make viable.  .

*Mitigation*:  Teh to negotiate

*Update 10/23:*  *{color:#de350b}MITIGATED{color}* - Capacity Block Govt Accounting issues are no longer.  We agree on the targeted price tag and some discount structure to build up to this. 

Tied to story - NOPT-5874 

 

*Risk*:  Surge Capacity can cost be more than block capacity.  It’d be a CAS violation if we charge a higher rate for the same service, which is currently the contract language if the capacity block is exceeded.  

*Mitigation*:  Teh will try to negotiate for the same rate if the hours exceed the block- otherwise finance would have to do a retroactive correction to all charge numbers to ensure rate parity throughout the year.

*Update 10/23:*  {color:#de350b}*MITIGATED*{color} - Discounted Rate Card Same or better than the capacity block rate.

Tied to story - NOPT-5874

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Initial Data Flow Diagram Design & Review
column35: Building out a new Splunk environment in AWS brings new technological benefits but also provides us with an opportunity to build on lessons learned and ensure we are building out our data collection tiers in a more efficient manner.  This decision needs to be agreed up and should follow Splunk best practices.  This will not only enhance the overall user experience, with search benefits of better data distribution, but it will also allow us to be more flexible and make changes without causing major impacts to the environment.As a Splunk team, we need to work with our Splunk Account team to verify available options, weight the key benefits to various design models and decide on the best solution for the initial RTX design.  We will architect the  Splunk Data Flow Digram based upon these recommendations and an agreed upon path forward. *Acceptance Criteria:* * There is a consensus on a path forward for our Data Ingest Tier * Initial DFD draft has been built out in it's entirety and shows the flows expected from RTX BUs and External Partners * Splunk team review, critiques, updates and sign off on DFD draft design * Management approval on draft design before moving forward with Cyber Architect and AWS Cloud Ops meetings

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Cyber Architecture/AWS Cloud Ops Acceptance & Approval
column35: Upon completion of the initial DFD draft (LCTOPST-159), we will meet with the leads from the Cyber Architecture and AWS Cloud Ops teams.  We will review our draft design with them, seeking guidance, validation, and approval before submitting for formal SAP/Archer review.  *Acceptance Criteria:* * Security Architecture pre-approves our going forward Splunk data flow design * AWS Cloud Ops validates our routing and provides input for necessary changes where applicable * All recommendations and necessary updates are captured for implementation and consideration for final DFD design

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Finalize Data Flow Diagram Design
column35: After meeting with the Cyber Architect and AWS Cloud Ops leads (LCTOPST-160) the Splunk teams will make the necessary updates and changes to the draft DFD.  These changes/updates will solidify the data flow from the RTX BUs and finalize the moving forward Splunk infrastructure and design strategy.  This diagram will provide our team with a template for design and a foundation for building out our Terraform Configuration files and Ansible Playbooks. *Acceptance Criteria:* * An approved DFD design has been fully developed and documented, incorporating all mandatory and agreed upon recommended changes * The DFD has been reviewed with the Splunk teams and validated prior to management approval * Once the team has finalized their DFD, we require management approval and validation * Submit Splunk design to SAP/Archer

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Define Tooling, Versions and Sources
column35: Define which tools, tool versions and download sources will be used for building environment. *Acceptance Criteria:* * Tools are downloaded and made available

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Build out Git Repository Structures for Infrastructure Build
column35: Build out the initial Git Repository, CTOPS-splunk-terraform, for Terraform code that deploys our Splunk infrastructure in AeroCloud. *Acceptance Criteria:* * Git Repo is built * Access is granted to COE and APE team members * Terraform code structure example

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Develop Code and Standup Splunk Aerocloud Infrastructure
column35: Once the the Git structure for Terraform Code is defined and we have access to the required tooling, we will begin developing the Terraform Code to deploy our Splunk infrastructure in AeroCloud.   *Acceptance Criteria:* * Splunk infrastructure servers are up and running in AeroCloud * Access to Splunk servers is available to the COE and APE teams * Standing up new & tearing down old Splunk servers in an automated fashion is a repeatable process ("idempotent" -Steve)

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Define and Build Ansible Playbooks and Roles to Deploy Splunk
column35: Define and build the Ansible Playbook and Role structures, for use when deploying the Splunk software and defining the Splunk server roles.  This will be used to configure the Splunk infrastructure, define their roles as Splunk servers and baseline the environment per Splunk PS Guidance. *Acceptance Criteria:* * All Splunk server roles are captured and defined (Management Servers, Search Heads, Search Head Clusters,  Indexer Clusters, Support Servers, etc)  * Baseline Apps are defined and configured to be deployed  * Splunk servers can be deployed and joined to the environment as needed * All team members understand how to deploy and manage the servers

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Deploy Splunk Application and Configure Server Roles in AeroCloud
column35: Once the Ansible Playbooks and Roles have been built (LCTOPST-166), we will begin the Splunk infrastructure build out and testing of the code.  Splunk will be stood up in AeroCloud and each server will have it's specific Splunk role applied to it (based on the DFD in LCTOPST-153) and configured properly to perform the necessary tasks.   *Acceptance Criteria:* * Splunk environment is stood up and baseline configured to our required specifications outlined in the DFD * Baseline apps are deployed successfully * Search Head Clusters and Indexer Clusters are configured and communicating properly * All servers are logging their local logs to the Splunk indexing tier * Custom server and web certificates are deployed and functioning properly *  WebUI and REST interfaces are accessible on the appropriate Search Heads * We can tear down and rebuild this environment repeatably (the environment is omnipotent)

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Update Code and Standup Splunk RTXCP Dev Infrastructure
column35: Once the Aerocloud Splunk infrastructure is successfully stood up  (LCTOPST-154) and RTXCP is available, we will update the Terraform Code to deploy our Splunk infrastructure in RTXCP.   *Acceptance Criteria:* * Splunk infrastructure servers are up and running in AeroCloud * Access to Splunk servers is available to the COE and APE teams * Standing up new & tearing down old Splunk servers in an automated fashion is a repeatable process ("idempotent" -Steve)

column1: SIEM Integration - 182751 - Deploy Splunk Application and Configure Server Roles in RTXCP
column35: Once the Ansible Playbooks and Roles have been updated (LCTOPST-168), we will begin the Splunk infrastructure build out and testing of the code in RTXCP.  Splunk will be stood up and each server will have it's specific Splunk role applied to it (based on the DFD in LCTOPST-153) and configured properly to perform the necessary tasks.   *Acceptance Criteria:* * Splunk environment is stood up and baseline configured to our required specifications outlined in the DFD * Baseline apps are deployed successfully * Search Head Clusters and Indexer Clusters are configured and communicating properly * All servers are logging their local logs to the Splunk indexing tier * Custom server and web certificates are deployed and functioning properly * WebUI and REST interfaces are accessible on the appropriate Search Heads * We can tear down and rebuild this environment repeatably (the environment is omnipotent)

15/Dec/21 4:35 PM;andy.chan@rtx.com;Closing this item based on information from Michele:

Based on this morning’s call we are officially closing out this portion of the network segmentation workstream.  There is a lot of interest in continuing this as a project outside of Optimus and I will work that through with Dan and Tyler and circle back with our stakeholder team to update them accordingly on what to expect.  I may not get that communication out until January depending on what those next steps are but will plan to do that so that everyone understands where this is landing. 
--------------------------------------------



With this discussion I will be formally closing out the work effort in the Network Transformation project.  Based on Tyler and Marty’s input, we are aligned that there is value to continuing to pursue this effort outside of the Optimus program however there are limited resources and funding at this time.

 

The recommended approach is to get this on the Cyber PMO radar for a 2022 work effort as a LAN and User Segmentation project.  This would allow us to further scope the capabilities, understand the current state of the environment and evaluate funding needs.  Also look at opportunities to enable capabilities in the new RTX remote access environment and potentially pilot the capability in Corp offices if the LAN supports 802.1x.  Ultimately we’ll want to gather the information needed to develop a roadmap for the next several years that will allow us to prepare and work this through the necessary funding and resource processes. 

 

I do want to circle back with all the stakeholders that were involved in helping develop this recommendation and set some expectations for the next steps so I’ll continue to work with Dan and Tyler to define that path forward.

---------------------------------------------

 

As part of the Optimus Network Transformation project under Marty Tice we’ve had a sub team working on network segmentation – how to ensure we maintain the existing compliance boundaries as we move into the new network, collapse/consolidate segmentation points in to the new performance hubs and has the flexibility to support organizational changes as well as compliance changes in the future. 

 

As a part of this sub team we’ve also been evaluating the capability Collins has been deploying using Cisco ISE for posture assessments integrated with the hub firewalls to provide additional controls for the cross boundary access within Collins. We’ve been engaging with key Cyber leads at RTX Corporate along with Pratt, Collins, RMD and RIS to review this capability and discuss how this can be leveraged in the future for RTX.  While there is great interest in pursuing this, continued effort on this is not in scope or budget for the Network Transformation project.


This meeting will be to review our recommendation to create a 2022 project for this, sponsored by RTX Enterprise Cybersecurity and Corporate Cybersecurity, in partnership with the Collins team and RTX EIS.

You will need to make a recommendation to your team on how to handle. This is more waterfall than agile. The rules I have learned for Leader’s Intent is that it should cover the who, what, where, and why, but not the HOW. That is up to you.
